title: Text Exploration and NLP Techniques
description: This quiz covers fundamental concepts and techniques in text exploration for Natural Language Processing (NLP), including frequency analysis, N-gram analysis, and more.

questions.question: What is the primary purpose of Frequency Analysis in text exploration?

answers.answer: To identify the grammatical structure of sentences.
To count the occurrences of words or terms to find common topics.
To determine the sentiment (positive, negative, neutral) of a text.
To reduce words to their root form.

questions.question: Which of the following metrics gives a higher weight to words that are frequent in a specific document but rare across the entire corpus?

answers.answer: Raw Frequency
Term Frequency (TF)
Term Frequency-Inverse Document Frequency (TF-IDF)
Type-Token Ratio (TTR)

questions.question: What is the technique of breaking down text into individual words or units called?

answers.answer: Stemming
Lemmatization
Tokenization
Stopword Removal

questions.question: In the context of N-gram analysis, what does a 'Bigram' refer to?

answers.answer: A sequence of three words.
A sequence of two words.
A single word or token.
A word with multiple meanings.

questions.question: What is the main application of Concordance (KWIC) analysis?

answers.answer: Generating a list of the most frequent words in a text.
Finding the sentiment of a text.
Identifying the root form of a word.
Understanding the different meanings and contexts of a specific word.

questions.question: Which metric is used in Collocation Analysis to measure the association between two words?

answers.answer: Flesch Reading Ease
Term Frequency
Pointwise Mutual Information (PMI)
Type-Token Ratio (TTR)

questions.question: What does a high score in the Type-Token Ratio (TTR) metric typically indicate?

answers.answer: A repetitive and simple writing style.
A high level of grammatical errors.
Greater lexical diversity and a wide range of vocabulary.
That the text is difficult to read.

questions.question: Which visualization strategy is commonly used to display the distribution of a word throughout a text?

answers.answer: Word Cloud
Bar Chart
Dispersion Plot
Network Graph

questions.question: The Flesch Reading Ease score is part of which analysis technique?

answers.answer: Collocation Analysis
Readability Analysis
Topic Modeling
Sentiment Analysis

questions.question: What is a key difference between Extractive and Abstractive Text Summarization?

answers.answer: Extractive summarization uses machine learning, while abstractive does not.
Extractive summarization creates a summary by selecting existing sentences, while abstractive generates new sentences.
Abstractive summarization is a rule-based method, while extractive is statistical.
Extractive summarization is used for long documents, while abstractive is for short texts.

questions.question: What is the primary goal of Named Entity Recognition (NER)?

answers.answer: To translate text from one language to another.
To identify and classify named entities (like persons, organizations, and locations) in a text.
To analyze the grammatical structure of sentences.
To determine if a text is factual or expresses an opinion.

questions.question: What does a negative polarity score typically indicate in Sentiment Analysis?

answers.answer: A positive opinion.
A neutral or mixed opinion.
A negative opinion.
That the text is a factual statement.

questions.question: Which of the following is a common model for Topic Modeling?

answers.answer: BERT
Latent Dirichlet Allocation (LDA)
Word2Vec
VADER

questions.question: What is the purpose of Semantic Role Labeling (SRL) in Semantic Analysis?

answers.answer: To identify the correct meaning of a word in context.
To convert words into numerical vectors.
To identify the roles words play in a sentence (e.g., who did what to whom).
To measure the association between two words.
It identifies the main topics of a document.
It removes common words like 'the' and 'a'.
It marks each word in a text as a particular part of speech (e.g., noun, verb).
It assesses the readability of a text.

questions.question: In Syntactic Parsing, what does a 'Parse Tree' represent?

answers.answer: The relationship between two collocating words.
The frequency of the most common words.
The syntactic structure of a sentence.
The sentiment of a text over time.
